trans-unit.source: Steps to failback from Azure to VMware
trans-unit.target: Steps to failback from Azure to VMware

trans-unit.source: This article describes how Azure Site Recovery and vContinuum tool can be used to failback a virtual machine back to VMware.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how Azure Site Recovery and vContinuum tool can be used to failback a virtual machine back to VMware.

trans-unit.source: This document will walk you through the steps you need to failback from Azure back to your VMware site.
trans-unit.target: This document will walk you through the steps you need to failback from Azure back to your VMware site.

trans-unit.source: You must have already followed the steps given in the tutorial for <linkText>VMware to Azure protection and recovery</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You must have already followed the steps given in the tutorial for <linkText>VMware to Azure protection and recovery</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: After a successful failover to Azure, the virtual machines will be available in the virtual machines tab.
trans-unit.target: After a successful failover to Azure, the virtual machines will be available in the virtual machines tab.

trans-unit.source: When you decide to failback – below are the steps you need to follow.
trans-unit.target: When you decide to failback – below are the steps you need to follow.

trans-unit.source: Note that when you failback from Azure back to your VMware site, the recovery can only be to a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Note that when you failback from Azure back to your VMware site, the recovery can only be to a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Even if your initial source on VMware was a physical machine, failover to Azure followed by a failback to VMware will convert it into a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Even if your initial source on VMware was a physical machine, failover to Azure followed by a failback to VMware will convert it into a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Install vContinuum server on-premises
trans-unit.target: Install vContinuum server on-premises

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: Configure it to point to the CS
trans-unit.target: Configure it to point to the CS

trans-unit.source: Deploy a PS on Azure
trans-unit.target: Deploy a PS on Azure

trans-unit.source: Install a MT on-premises
trans-unit.target: Install a MT on-premises

trans-unit.source: Steps to protect the failed over VMs back to on-premises
trans-unit.target: Steps to protect the failed over VMs back to on-premises

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: Configuration considerations
trans-unit.target: Configuration considerations

trans-unit.source: Monitoring protection of VMs back to on-premises
trans-unit.target: Monitoring protection of VMs back to on-premises

trans-unit.source: Failover the VMs back to on-premises
trans-unit.target: Failover the VMs back to on-premises

trans-unit.source: Below is the setup overview that we will achieve with the below steps.
trans-unit.target: Below is the setup overview that we will achieve with the below steps.

trans-unit.source: Part of the setup has already been completed during failover.
trans-unit.target: Part of the setup has already been completed during failover.

trans-unit.source: The blue lines are the connections used during failover.
trans-unit.target: The blue lines are the connections used during failover.

trans-unit.source: The red lines are the connections used during failback.
trans-unit.target: The red lines are the connections used during failback.

trans-unit.source: The lines with arrows go over the internet.
trans-unit.target: The lines with arrows go over the internet.

trans-unit.source: The vContinuum setup will be at available at <linkText>download location</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The vContinuum setup will be at available at <linkText>download location</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In addition install the patch given here on the vContinuum - available at <linkText>download location</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: In addition install the patch given here on the vContinuum - available at <linkText>download location</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Launch the setup to begin installation of vContinuum.
trans-unit.target: Launch the setup to begin installation of vContinuum.

trans-unit.source: Click Next.
trans-unit.target: Click Next.

trans-unit.source: Specify the CX server IP address and the CX server port.
trans-unit.target: Specify the CX server IP address and the CX server port.

trans-unit.source: Select HTTPS.
trans-unit.target: Select HTTPS.

trans-unit.source: To discover the CX IP address go to the CS deployment on Azure and view its dashboard.
trans-unit.target: To discover the CX IP address go to the CS deployment on Azure and view its dashboard.

trans-unit.source: To discover the CX public port go to the endpoints tab in the VM page and identify the HTTPs endpoints public port.
trans-unit.target: To discover the CX public port go to the endpoints tab in the VM page and identify the HTTPs endpoints public port.

trans-unit.source: Specify the CS Passphrase.
trans-unit.target: Specify the CS Passphrase.

trans-unit.source: You need to have noted down the passphrase during the CS registration.
trans-unit.target: You need to have noted down the passphrase during the CS registration.

trans-unit.source: You would have used the passphrase during MT and PS deployments also.
trans-unit.target: You would have used the passphrase during MT and PS deployments also.

trans-unit.source: In case you do not remember the passphrase you can go in to the CS server on Azure and find the passphrase stored under C:\\Program Files (x86)\\InMage Systems\\private\\connection.passphrase
trans-unit.target: In case you do not remember the passphrase you can go in to the CS server on Azure and find the passphrase stored under C:\\Program Files (x86)\\InMage Systems\\private\\connection.passphrase

trans-unit.source: Specify the location to install the vContinuum server and begin installation.
trans-unit.target: Specify the location to install the vContinuum server and begin installation.

trans-unit.source: Once you see that installation completes, you can launch the vContinuum to see it working.
trans-unit.target: Once you see that installation completes, you can launch the vContinuum to see it working.

trans-unit.source: A Process Server needs to be installed on Azure so that the VMs in Azure can send the data back to on-premises MT.
trans-unit.target: A Process Server needs to be installed on Azure so that the VMs in Azure can send the data back to on-premises MT.

trans-unit.source: You need to deploy the PS on Azure in the same network as the Configuration Server.
trans-unit.target: You need to deploy the PS on Azure in the same network as the Configuration Server.

trans-unit.source: On the Configuration Servers page in Azure, select to add a new process server.
trans-unit.target: On the Configuration Servers page in Azure, select to add a new process server.

trans-unit.source: Specify a process server name, and enter a name and password to connect to the virtual machine as an admin.
trans-unit.target: Specify a process server name, and enter a name and password to connect to the virtual machine as an admin.

trans-unit.source: Select the configuration server to which you're registering the process server.
trans-unit.target: Select the configuration server to which you're registering the process server.

trans-unit.source: This should be the same server you're using to protect and fail over your virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: This should be the same server you're using to protect and fail over your virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Specify the Azure ntwork in which the process server should be deployment.
trans-unit.target: Specify the Azure ntwork in which the process server should be deployment.

trans-unit.source: It should be the same network as the configuration server.
trans-unit.target: It should be the same network as the configuration server.

trans-unit.source: Specify a unique IP address from the select subnet and begin deployment.
trans-unit.target: Specify a unique IP address from the select subnet and begin deployment.

trans-unit.source: A job to deploy the process server will be triggered.
trans-unit.target: A job to deploy the process server will be triggered.

trans-unit.source: Once the process server is deployed on Azure you can log into the server using the credentials you specified.
trans-unit.target: Once the process server is deployed on Azure you can log into the server using the credentials you specified.

trans-unit.source: Use the same steps you used during forward direction of protection to register the PS.
trans-unit.target: Use the same steps you used during forward direction of protection to register the PS.

trans-unit.source: The servers registered during failback will not be visible under VM properties.
trans-unit.target: The servers registered during failback will not be visible under VM properties.

trans-unit.source: They will be only visible under the Servers tab under the Configuration server to which they have been registered.
trans-unit.target: They will be only visible under the Servers tab under the Configuration server to which they have been registered.

trans-unit.source: It can take about 10-15 mins for the PS to be listed under the CS.
trans-unit.target: It can take about 10-15 mins for the PS to be listed under the CS.

trans-unit.source: Depending on the source side virtual machines you need to install a Linux or a Windows Master Target server on-premises.
trans-unit.target: Depending on the source side virtual machines you need to install a Linux or a Windows Master Target server on-premises.

trans-unit.source: A windows MT is already bundled with vContinuum setup.
trans-unit.target: A windows MT is already bundled with vContinuum setup.

trans-unit.source: When you install the vContinuum, an MT is also deployed on the same machine and registered to the Configuration server.
trans-unit.target: When you install the vContinuum, an MT is also deployed on the same machine and registered to the Configuration server.

trans-unit.source: To begin deployment, create an empty machine on-premises on the ESX host onto which you want to recover the VMs from Auzre.
trans-unit.target: To begin deployment, create an empty machine on-premises on the ESX host onto which you want to recover the VMs from Auzre.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that there are at least two disks attached to the VM – one is used for the OS and the second one is used for Retention Drive.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that there are at least two disks attached to the VM – one is used for the OS and the second one is used for Retention Drive.

trans-unit.source: Install the operating system.
trans-unit.target: Install the operating system.

trans-unit.source: Install the vContinuum on the server.
trans-unit.target: Install the vContinuum on the server.

trans-unit.source: This would also complete installation of the MT.
trans-unit.target: This would also complete installation of the MT.

trans-unit.source: To begin deployment, create an empty machine on-premises on the ESX host onto which you want to recover the VMs from Auzre.
trans-unit.target: To begin deployment, create an empty machine on-premises on the ESX host onto which you want to recover the VMs from Auzre.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that there are at least two disks attached to the VM – one is used for the OS and the second one is used for Retention Drive.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that there are at least two disks attached to the VM – one is used for the OS and the second one is used for Retention Drive.

trans-unit.source: Install the linux operating system.
trans-unit.target: Install the linux operating system.

trans-unit.source: NLinux Master Target (MT) system should not use LVM for root or retention storage spaces.
trans-unit.target: NLinux Master Target (MT) system should not use LVM for root or retention storage spaces.

trans-unit.source: Linux MT configured to avoid LVM partitions/disks discovery by default.
trans-unit.target: Linux MT configured to avoid LVM partitions/disks discovery by default.

trans-unit.source: Partitions that you can create are
trans-unit.target: Partitions that you can create are

trans-unit.source: Carry out the below post installation steps before beginning MT installation.
trans-unit.target: Carry out the below post installation steps before beginning MT installation.

trans-unit.source: To get SCSI ID’s for each of SCSI hard disk in a Linux virtual machine, you should enable the parameter “disk.EnableUUID = TRUE”.
trans-unit.target: To get SCSI ID’s for each of SCSI hard disk in a Linux virtual machine, you should enable the parameter “disk.EnableUUID = TRUE”.

trans-unit.source: To enable this parameter, follow the steps as given below:
trans-unit.target: To enable this parameter, follow the steps as given below:

trans-unit.source: Shut down your virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Shut down your virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Right-click the VM’s entry in the left-hand panel > Edit Settings.
trans-unit.target: Right-click the VM’s entry in the left-hand panel > Edit Settings.

trans-unit.source: Click the Options tab.
trans-unit.target: Click the Options tab.

trans-unit.source: Select the Advanced\>General item on the left and click the Configuration Parameters that you see on the right.
trans-unit.target: Select the Advanced\>General item on the left and click the Configuration Parameters that you see on the right.

trans-unit.source: “Configuration Parameters” option will be in de-active state when the machine is running”.
trans-unit.target: “Configuration Parameters” option will be in de-active state when the machine is running”.

trans-unit.source: In order to make this tab active, shutdown machine.
trans-unit.target: In order to make this tab active, shutdown machine.

trans-unit.source: See whether already a row with disk.EnableUUID exists?
trans-unit.target: See whether already a row with disk.EnableUUID exists?

trans-unit.source: If exists and if the value is set to False over write the value with True (True and False values are case in-sensitive).
trans-unit.target: If exists and if the value is set to False over write the value with True (True and False values are case in-sensitive).

trans-unit.source: If exists and is set to true, click on cancel and test the SCSI command inside guest operating system after it is boot-up.
trans-unit.target: If exists and is set to true, click on cancel and test the SCSI command inside guest operating system after it is boot-up.

trans-unit.source: If does not exist click Add Row.
trans-unit.target: If does not exist click Add Row.

trans-unit.source: Add disk.EnableUUID in the Name column.
trans-unit.target: Add disk.EnableUUID in the Name column.

trans-unit.source: Set its value as TRUE.
trans-unit.target: Set its value as TRUE.

trans-unit.source: Do not add the above values along with double-quotes.
trans-unit.target: Do not add the above values along with double-quotes.

trans-unit.source: NOTE: Make sure system has Internet connectivity before download and installing additional packages.
trans-unit.target: NOTE: Make sure system has Internet connectivity before download and installing additional packages.

trans-unit.source: \# yum install -y xfsprogs perl lsscsi rsync wget kexec-tools
trans-unit.target: \# yum install -y xfsprogs perl lsscsi rsync wget kexec-tools

trans-unit.source: Above command will download below mentioned 15 packages from CentOS 6.6 repository and install.
trans-unit.target: Above command will download below mentioned 15 packages from CentOS 6.6 repository and install.

trans-unit.source: elfutils-libs-0.158-3.2.el6.x86\_64.rpm
trans-unit.target: elfutils-libs-0.158-3.2.el6.x86\_64.rpm

trans-unit.source: kexec-tools-2.0.0-280.el6.x86\_64.rpm
trans-unit.target: kexec-tools-2.0.0-280.el6.x86\_64.rpm

trans-unit.source: lsscsi-0.23-2.el6.x86\_64.rpm
trans-unit.target: lsscsi-0.23-2.el6.x86\_64.rpm

trans-unit.source: perl-Module-Pluggable-3.90-136.el6\6.1.x86\64.rpm
trans-unit.target: perl-Module-Pluggable-3.90-136.el6\6.1.x86\64.rpm

trans-unit.source: perl-Pod-Escapes-1.04-136.el6\6.1.x86\64.rpm
trans-unit.target: perl-Pod-Escapes-1.04-136.el6\6.1.x86\64.rpm

trans-unit.source: perl-Pod-Simple-3.13-136.el6\6.1.x86\64.rpm
trans-unit.target: perl-Pod-Simple-3.13-136.el6\6.1.x86\64.rpm

trans-unit.source: perl-version-0.77-136.el6\6.1.x86\64.rpm
trans-unit.target: perl-version-0.77-136.el6\6.1.x86\64.rpm

trans-unit.source: snappy-1.1.0-1.el6.x86\_64.rpm
trans-unit.target: snappy-1.1.0-1.el6.x86\_64.rpm

trans-unit.source: NOTE: If source machine uses Reiser or XFS filesystem for root or boot device, then following packages should be download and installed on Linux Master Target prior to the protection.
trans-unit.target: NOTE: If source machine uses Reiser or XFS filesystem for root or boot device, then following packages should be download and installed on Linux Master Target prior to the protection.

trans-unit.source: \# cd /usr/local
trans-unit.target: \# cd /usr/local

trans-unit.source: \# wget 64/RPMS/kmod-reiserfs-0.0-1.el6.elrepo.x8664.rpm>
trans-unit.target: \# wget 64/RPMS/kmod-reiserfs-0.0-1.el6.elrepo.x8664.rpm>

trans-unit.source: \# wget 64/RPMS/reiserfs-utils-3.6.21-1.el6.elrepo.x8664.rpm>
trans-unit.target: \# wget 64/RPMS/reiserfs-utils-3.6.21-1.el6.elrepo.x8664.rpm>

trans-unit.source: \# rpm -ivh kmod-reiserfs-0.0-1.el6.elrepo.x86\64.rpm reiserfs-utils-3.6.21-1.el6.elrepo.x86\64.rpm
trans-unit.target: \# rpm -ivh kmod-reiserfs-0.0-1.el6.elrepo.x86\64.rpm reiserfs-utils-3.6.21-1.el6.elrepo.x86\64.rpm

trans-unit.source: \# wget 64/Packages/xfsprogs-3.1.1-16.el6.x8664.rpm>
trans-unit.target: \# wget 64/Packages/xfsprogs-3.1.1-16.el6.x8664.rpm>

trans-unit.source: \# rpm -ivh xfsprogs-3.1.1-16.el6.x86\_64.rpm
trans-unit.target: \# rpm -ivh xfsprogs-3.1.1-16.el6.x86\_64.rpm

trans-unit.source: Before applying custom configuration changes make sure you have completed Post Installation Steps
trans-unit.target: Before applying custom configuration changes make sure you have completed Post Installation Steps

trans-unit.source: To apply custom configuration changes, follow the below mentioned steps:
trans-unit.target: To apply custom configuration changes, follow the below mentioned steps:

trans-unit.source: Copy the RHEL 6-64 Unified Agent binary to the newly created OS.
trans-unit.target: Copy the RHEL 6-64 Unified Agent binary to the newly created OS.

trans-unit.source: Run the below command to untar the binary.
trans-unit.target: Run the below command to untar the binary.

trans-unit.source: tar -zxvf \
trans-unit.target: tar -zxvf \

trans-unit.source: Execute below command to give permission.
trans-unit.target: Execute below command to give permission.

trans-unit.source: \# chmod 755 ./ApplyCustomChanges.sh
trans-unit.target: \# chmod 755 ./ApplyCustomChanges.sh

trans-unit.source: Execute the below command to run the script.
trans-unit.target: Execute the below command to run the script.

trans-unit.source: \# ./ApplyCustomChanges.sh
trans-unit.target: \# ./ApplyCustomChanges.sh

trans-unit.source: NOTE: Execute the script only once on the server.
trans-unit.target: NOTE: Execute the script only once on the server.

trans-unit.source: REBOOT the server after successful execution of the above script.
trans-unit.target: REBOOT the server after successful execution of the above script.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Download</linkText><title></title> the Linux Master Target Server installation file.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Download</linkText><title></title> the Linux Master Target Server installation file.

trans-unit.source: Copy the downloaded Linux Master Target Server installer to the Linux Master Target virtual machine using an sftp client utility of your choice.
trans-unit.target: Copy the downloaded Linux Master Target Server installer to the Linux Master Target virtual machine using an sftp client utility of your choice.

trans-unit.source: Alternately you can log into the Linux Master Target virtual machine and use wget to download the installation package from the provided link.
trans-unit.target: Alternately you can log into the Linux Master Target virtual machine and use wget to download the installation package from the provided link.

trans-unit.source: Log in to the Linux Master Target server virtual machine using an ssh client of your choice.
trans-unit.target: Log in to the Linux Master Target server virtual machine using an ssh client of your choice.

trans-unit.source: If you are connected to the Azure network on which you deployed your Linux Master Target server through a VPN connection then use the internal IP address for the Linux Master Target Server obtained from the virtual machine dashboard and port 22 to connect to the Linux Master Target Server using Secure Shell.
trans-unit.target: If you are connected to the Azure network on which you deployed your Linux Master Target server through a VPN connection then use the internal IP address for the Linux Master Target Server obtained from the virtual machine dashboard and port 22 to connect to the Linux Master Target Server using Secure Shell.

trans-unit.source: If you are connecting to the Linux Master Target Server over a public internet connection use the Linux Master Target Server’s public virtual IP address (from the virtual machines dashboard page) and the public endpoint created for ssh to login to the Linux Master Target Server.
trans-unit.target: If you are connecting to the Linux Master Target Server over a public internet connection use the Linux Master Target Server’s public virtual IP address (from the virtual machines dashboard page) and the public endpoint created for ssh to login to the Linux Master Target Server.

trans-unit.source: Extract the files from the gzipped Linux Master Target Server installer tar archive by executing
trans-unit.target: Extract the files from the gzipped Linux Master Target Server installer tar archive by executing

trans-unit.source: “tar –xvzf Microsoft-ASR\_UA\_8.2.0.0\_RHEL6-64\”* from the directory where you had copied the Linux Master Target Server installer to.
trans-unit.target: “tar –xvzf Microsoft-ASR\_UA\_8.2.0.0\_RHEL6-64\”* from the directory where you had copied the Linux Master Target Server installer to.

trans-unit.source: If you extracted the installer files to a different directory change directory to the directory to which the contents of the tar archive were extracted.
trans-unit.target: If you extracted the installer files to a different directory change directory to the directory to which the contents of the tar archive were extracted.

trans-unit.source: From this directory path execute “sudo ./install.sh”
trans-unit.target: From this directory path execute “sudo ./install.sh”

trans-unit.source: When prompted to make choice of Primary Role of this Agent select 2 (Master Target)
trans-unit.target: When prompted to make choice of Primary Role of this Agent select 2 (Master Target)

trans-unit.source: Leave the other interactive install options at their default values.
trans-unit.target: Leave the other interactive install options at their default values.

trans-unit.source: Wait for the rest of the installation to proceed and the Host Config Interface to appear.
trans-unit.target: Wait for the rest of the installation to proceed and the Host Config Interface to appear.

trans-unit.source: The Host Configuration utility for the Linux Master Target Server is a command line utility.
trans-unit.target: The Host Configuration utility for the Linux Master Target Server is a command line utility.

trans-unit.source: Don’t resize your ssh client utility window.
trans-unit.target: Don’t resize your ssh client utility window.

trans-unit.source: Use the arrow keys to select the Global option and press enter on your keyboard.
trans-unit.target: Use the arrow keys to select the Global option and press enter on your keyboard.

trans-unit.source: Against the field IP enter the Internal IP address of the Configuration Server obtained from the virtual machines dashboard page and press enter.
trans-unit.target: Against the field IP enter the Internal IP address of the Configuration Server obtained from the virtual machines dashboard page and press enter.

trans-unit.source: Against the field Port enter 22 and press enter.
trans-unit.target: Against the field Port enter 22 and press enter.

trans-unit.source: Leave Use https: as Yes.
trans-unit.target: Leave Use https: as Yes.

trans-unit.source: Press enter one more time.
trans-unit.target: Press enter one more time.

trans-unit.source: Enter the Passphrase that was generated on the Configuration Server.
trans-unit.target: Enter the Passphrase that was generated on the Configuration Server.

trans-unit.source: If you are using PuTTY client from a Windows machine to ssh to the Linux Master Target Server virtual machine you can use Shift+Insert to paste the contents of the clipboard.
trans-unit.target: If you are using PuTTY client from a Windows machine to ssh to the Linux Master Target Server virtual machine you can use Shift+Insert to paste the contents of the clipboard.

trans-unit.source: Copy the Passphrase to the local clipboard using Ctrl-C and use Shift+Insert to paste it.
trans-unit.target: Copy the Passphrase to the local clipboard using Ctrl-C and use Shift+Insert to paste it.

trans-unit.source: Press enter
trans-unit.target: Press enter

trans-unit.source: Use the right arrow key to navigate to quit and press enter.
trans-unit.target: Use the right arrow key to navigate to quit and press enter.

trans-unit.source: Wait for the installation to complete
trans-unit.target: Wait for the installation to complete

trans-unit.source: If for some reason you failed to register your Linux Master Target Server to the Configuration Server you could do so again by running the host configuration utility from /usr/local/ASR/Vx/bin/hostconfigcli (you will first need to set access permissions to this directory by executing chmod as a super user)
trans-unit.target: If for some reason you failed to register your Linux Master Target Server to the Configuration Server you could do so again by running the host configuration utility from /usr/local/ASR/Vx/bin/hostconfigcli (you will first need to set access permissions to this directory by executing chmod as a super user)

trans-unit.source: You can validate that the Master Target Server registered successfully with the Configuration Server by visiting the Server Details page under the Configuration Server page on the Azure Site Recovery vault
trans-unit.target: You can validate that the Master Target Server registered successfully with the Configuration Server by visiting the Server Details page under the Configuration Server page on the Azure Site Recovery vault

trans-unit.source: Before failback of the VMs back to on-premises, first you need to protect the virtual machines back to on-premises.
trans-unit.target: Before failback of the VMs back to on-premises, first you need to protect the virtual machines back to on-premises.

trans-unit.source: Follow the below steps to protect VMs of an application.
trans-unit.target: Follow the below steps to protect VMs of an application.

trans-unit.source: When a VM is failed over to Azure, it adds an extra temp drive for page file.
trans-unit.target: When a VM is failed over to Azure, it adds an extra temp drive for page file.

trans-unit.source: This is an extra drive that is typically not required by your failed over VM since it might already have a drive dedicated for the page file.
trans-unit.target: This is an extra drive that is typically not required by your failed over VM since it might already have a drive dedicated for the page file.

trans-unit.source: Before you begin reverse protection of the virtual machines, you need to ensure that the drive is taken offline so that it does not get protected.
trans-unit.target: Before you begin reverse protection of the virtual machines, you need to ensure that the drive is taken offline so that it does not get protected.

trans-unit.source: To do this,
trans-unit.target: To do this,

trans-unit.source: Open Computer Management (via control panel administrative tool, or by right click on This PC in the explorer window and selecting manage.)
trans-unit.target: Open Computer Management (via control panel administrative tool, or by right click on This PC in the explorer window and selecting manage.)

trans-unit.source: Select Storage Management so that it lists the disks online and attached to the machine.
trans-unit.target: Select Storage Management so that it lists the disks online and attached to the machine.

trans-unit.source: Select the temporary disk attached to the machine and choose to bring it offline.
trans-unit.target: Select the temporary disk attached to the machine and choose to bring it offline.

trans-unit.source: Once it has been successfully taken offline you can proceed with protecting the virtual machine in the reverse direction.
trans-unit.target: Once it has been successfully taken offline you can proceed with protecting the virtual machine in the reverse direction.

trans-unit.source: On the Azure portal, look at the states of the virtual machine and ensure that they are failed over.
trans-unit.target: On the Azure portal, look at the states of the virtual machine and ensure that they are failed over.

trans-unit.source: Note : during failover from Azure back to on-premises, the Azure VM is considered similar to a Physical VM.
trans-unit.target: Note : during failover from Azure back to on-premises, the Azure VM is considered similar to a Physical VM.

trans-unit.source: The failover to on-premises is to a virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: The failover to on-premises is to a virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Launch the vContinuum on your machine
trans-unit.target: Launch the vContinuum on your machine

trans-unit.source: In the Choose Application setting, select P2V
trans-unit.target: In the Choose Application setting, select P2V

trans-unit.source: Click on the New Protection option to begin
trans-unit.target: Click on the New Protection option to begin

trans-unit.source: In the new window that opens you will begin protecting the virtual machines back to on-premises.
trans-unit.target: In the new window that opens you will begin protecting the virtual machines back to on-premises.

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: Select the OS type according to the VMs you want to failback and Get Details
trans-unit.target: Select the OS type according to the VMs you want to failback and Get Details

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: In the Primary server details, you need to identify the virtual machines that you want to protect.
trans-unit.target: In the Primary server details, you need to identify the virtual machines that you want to protect.

trans-unit.source: c.
trans-unit.target: c.

trans-unit.source: The virtual machines are listed by their Computer Hostnames and not as they are visible on vCenter or Azure
trans-unit.target: The virtual machines are listed by their Computer Hostnames and not as they are visible on vCenter or Azure

trans-unit.source: d.
trans-unit.target: d.

trans-unit.source: The virtual machines are listed under the vCenter Hostname that the virtual machines were on, before failover.
trans-unit.target: The virtual machines are listed under the vCenter Hostname that the virtual machines were on, before failover.

trans-unit.source: e.
trans-unit.target: e.

trans-unit.source: Once you have identified the VMs you want to protect, select them one by one.
trans-unit.target: Once you have identified the VMs you want to protect, select them one by one.

trans-unit.source: When you select a virtual machine to protect (and it has already failed over to Azure) you will get a popup window that gives two entries for the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: When you select a virtual machine to protect (and it has already failed over to Azure) you will get a popup window that gives two entries for the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: This is because the CS has detected two instances of the virtual machines registered to it.
trans-unit.target: This is because the CS has detected two instances of the virtual machines registered to it.

trans-unit.source: You need to remove the entry for the on-premises VM so that you can protect the correct VM.
trans-unit.target: You need to remove the entry for the on-premises VM so that you can protect the correct VM.

trans-unit.source: Note that you will see the entries by its computer hostname.
trans-unit.target: Note that you will see the entries by its computer hostname.

trans-unit.source: To identify the correct Azure VM entry here, you can log into the Azure VM and go to C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Azure Site Recovery\Application Data\etc. In the file drscout.conf , identify the Host ID.
trans-unit.target: To identify the correct Azure VM entry here, you can log into the Azure VM and go to C:\Program Files (x86)\Microsoft Azure Site Recovery\Application Data\etc. In the file drscout.conf , identify the Host ID.

trans-unit.source: In the vContinuum dialog, keep the entry for which the hostID is found in the VM.
trans-unit.target: In the vContinuum dialog, keep the entry for which the hostID is found in the VM.

trans-unit.source: Delete all other entries.
trans-unit.target: Delete all other entries.

trans-unit.source: To select the correct VM you can refer to its IP address.
trans-unit.target: To select the correct VM you can refer to its IP address.

trans-unit.source: The IP address range on-premises will be the on-premises VM.
trans-unit.target: The IP address range on-premises will be the on-premises VM.

trans-unit.source: Click Remove to delete the entry.
trans-unit.target: Click Remove to delete the entry.

trans-unit.source: Go to the vCenter and stop the virtual machine on the vCenter
trans-unit.target: Go to the vCenter and stop the virtual machine on the vCenter

trans-unit.source: Next you can also delete the virtual machines on-premises
trans-unit.target: Next you can also delete the virtual machines on-premises

trans-unit.source: Next you need to specify the on-premises MT server to which you want to protect the VMs.
trans-unit.target: Next you need to specify the on-premises MT server to which you want to protect the VMs.

trans-unit.source: To do this, connect to the vCenter to which you want to failback to
trans-unit.target: To do this, connect to the vCenter to which you want to failback to

trans-unit.source: Select the MT server based on the host into which you want to recover the virtual machines
trans-unit.target: Select the MT server based on the host into which you want to recover the virtual machines

trans-unit.source: Next provide the replication option for each of the virtual machines
trans-unit.target: Next provide the replication option for each of the virtual machines

trans-unit.source: To do this you need to select the recovery side Datastore – this is the datastore to which the VMs will be recovered to
trans-unit.target: To do this you need to select the recovery side Datastore – this is the datastore to which the VMs will be recovered to

trans-unit.source: The different options you need to provide per VM are
trans-unit.target: The different options you need to provide per VM are

trans-unit.source: Option
trans-unit.target: Option

trans-unit.source: Option recommended value
trans-unit.target: Option recommended value

trans-unit.source: Process Server IP
trans-unit.target: Process Server IP

trans-unit.source: Select the PS which you have deployed on Azure
trans-unit.target: Select the PS which you have deployed on Azure

trans-unit.source: Retention size in MB
trans-unit.target: Retention size in MB

trans-unit.source: Retention value
trans-unit.target: Retention value

trans-unit.source: Days/Hours
trans-unit.target: Days/Hours

trans-unit.source: Days
trans-unit.target: Days

trans-unit.source: Consistency Interval
trans-unit.target: Consistency Interval

trans-unit.source: Select Target Datastore
trans-unit.target: Select Target Datastore

trans-unit.source: The datastore available on the recovery side.
trans-unit.target: The datastore available on the recovery side.

trans-unit.source: This data store should have enough space and also be available to the ESX host on which you want to realise the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: This data store should have enough space and also be available to the ESX host on which you want to realise the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Next you can configure the properties that the virtual machine will acquire after failover to on-premises site.
trans-unit.target: Next you can configure the properties that the virtual machine will acquire after failover to on-premises site.

trans-unit.source: The different properties you can configure are as below
trans-unit.target: The different properties you can configure are as below

trans-unit.source: Property
trans-unit.target: Property

trans-unit.source: How to configure
trans-unit.target: How to configure

trans-unit.source: Network Configuration
trans-unit.target: Network Configuration

trans-unit.source: For each NIC detected, configure the failback IP address for the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: For each NIC detected, configure the failback IP address for the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Select the NIC and click Change to specify the IP address details.
trans-unit.target: Select the NIC and click Change to specify the IP address details.

trans-unit.source: Hardware Configuration
trans-unit.target: Hardware Configuration

trans-unit.source: You can specify the CPU and the Memory values for the VM.
trans-unit.target: You can specify the CPU and the Memory values for the VM.

trans-unit.source: This setting can be applied to all the VMs you are trying to protect.
trans-unit.target: This setting can be applied to all the VMs you are trying to protect.

trans-unit.source: Display Name
trans-unit.target: Display Name

trans-unit.source: To identify the correct values for the CPU and Memory, you can refer to the IAAS VMs role size and see the number of cores and Memory assigned.
trans-unit.target: To identify the correct values for the CPU and Memory, you can refer to the IAAS VMs role size and see the number of cores and Memory assigned.

trans-unit.source: Display Name
trans-unit.target: Display Name

trans-unit.source: After failover back to on-premises, you can choose to rename the virtual machines as it will be seen in the inventory of vCenter.
trans-unit.target: After failover back to on-premises, you can choose to rename the virtual machines as it will be seen in the inventory of vCenter.

trans-unit.source: Note that the default value seen here is the virtual machine computer host name.
trans-unit.target: Note that the default value seen here is the virtual machine computer host name.

trans-unit.source: To identify the VM name, you can refer to the VM list in the Protection group.
trans-unit.target: To identify the VM name, you can refer to the VM list in the Protection group.

trans-unit.source: NAT Configuration
trans-unit.target: NAT Configuration

trans-unit.source: Discussed in detail below
trans-unit.target: Discussed in detail below

trans-unit.source: PS NAT settings choices
trans-unit.target: PS NAT settings choices

trans-unit.source: To enable protection of the virtual machines, two communication channels need to be established.
trans-unit.target: To enable protection of the virtual machines, two communication channels need to be established.

trans-unit.source: The first channel is between the virtual machine and the Process Server.
trans-unit.target: The first channel is between the virtual machine and the Process Server.

trans-unit.source: This channel collects the data from the VM and sends it to the PS.
trans-unit.target: This channel collects the data from the VM and sends it to the PS.

trans-unit.source: PS will then send this data to the Master Target.
trans-unit.target: PS will then send this data to the Master Target.

trans-unit.source: If the process server and the virtual machine to be protected are on the same Azure vNet, then you do not need to use the NAT settings.
trans-unit.target: If the process server and the virtual machine to be protected are on the same Azure vNet, then you do not need to use the NAT settings.

trans-unit.source: If the PS and the virtual machine to be protected is in two different vNet, then you need to specify the NAT settings for the PS and check the first option.
trans-unit.target: If the PS and the virtual machine to be protected is in two different vNet, then you need to specify the NAT settings for the PS and check the first option.

trans-unit.source: To identify the Process server Public IP, you can go to the PS deployment in Azure and see its Public IP address.
trans-unit.target: To identify the Process server Public IP, you can go to the PS deployment in Azure and see its Public IP address.

trans-unit.source: The second channel is between the Process server and the Master target.
trans-unit.target: The second channel is between the Process server and the Master target.

trans-unit.source: The option to use NAT or not depends on whether you are using VPN based connection between MT and PS or protecting over the internet.
trans-unit.target: The option to use NAT or not depends on whether you are using VPN based connection between MT and PS or protecting over the internet.

trans-unit.source: If the PS communicates to the MT over a VPN, then you should not select this option.
trans-unit.target: If the PS communicates to the MT over a VPN, then you should not select this option.

trans-unit.source: If the Master Target needs to communicate to the Process server over the internet, then specify the NAT settings for the PS.
trans-unit.target: If the Master Target needs to communicate to the Process server over the internet, then specify the NAT settings for the PS.

trans-unit.source: To identify the Process server Public IP, you can go to the PS deployment in Azure and see its Public IP address.
trans-unit.target: To identify the Process server Public IP, you can go to the PS deployment in Azure and see its Public IP address.

trans-unit.source: If you have not deleted the on-premises virtual machines as specified in Step 5.d, and if the datastore you are failing back to, as selected in step 7.a still contains the old VMDK’s then you will also need to ensure that the failback VM gets created in a new place.
trans-unit.target: If you have not deleted the on-premises virtual machines as specified in Step 5.d, and if the datastore you are failing back to, as selected in step 7.a still contains the old VMDK’s then you will also need to ensure that the failback VM gets created in a new place.

trans-unit.source: For this you can select the Advanced settings and specify an alternate Folder to restore to in the Folder Name Settings section of the Advanced Settings.
trans-unit.target: For this you can select the Advanced settings and specify an alternate Folder to restore to in the Folder Name Settings section of the Advanced Settings.

trans-unit.source: The other options in the Advanced settings can be left as default.
trans-unit.target: The other options in the Advanced settings can be left as default.

trans-unit.source: Make sure you apply the folder name settings to all the servers.
trans-unit.target: Make sure you apply the folder name settings to all the servers.

trans-unit.source: Next move to the final stage of the Protection.
trans-unit.target: Next move to the final stage of the Protection.

trans-unit.source: Here you need to run a Readiness Check to ensure that the virtual machines are ready to be protected back to on-premises.
trans-unit.target: Here you need to run a Readiness Check to ensure that the virtual machines are ready to be protected back to on-premises.

trans-unit.source: The Protection will now begin.
trans-unit.target: The Protection will now begin.

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: You can see the progress of the protection on the vContinuum
trans-unit.target: You can see the progress of the protection on the vContinuum

trans-unit.source: You can also see the exact status of the pairs by clicking into the virtual machine and monitoring its progress under the volume replication section.
trans-unit.target: You can also see the exact status of the pairs by clicking into the virtual machine and monitoring its progress under the volume replication section.

trans-unit.source: You can prepare a failback plan using vContinuum so that the application can be failed over back to on-premises at any time.
trans-unit.target: You can prepare a failback plan using vContinuum so that the application can be failed over back to on-premises at any time.

trans-unit.source: These recovery plans are very similar to the ASR Recovery plans.
trans-unit.target: These recovery plans are very similar to the ASR Recovery plans.

trans-unit.source: Launch the vContinuum and select the option to Manage plans.
trans-unit.target: Launch the vContinuum and select the option to Manage plans.

trans-unit.source: User the sub-options select Recover.
trans-unit.target: User the sub-options select Recover.

trans-unit.source: You can see the list of all the Plans that have been used to protect the virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: You can see the list of all the Plans that have been used to protect the virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: These are the same plans you can use to recover.
trans-unit.target: These are the same plans you can use to recover.

trans-unit.source: Select the Protection Plan and select all the VMs you want to recover within it.
trans-unit.target: Select the Protection Plan and select all the VMs you want to recover within it.

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: On selecting each VM you can see more details about the source VM, target ESX server where the VM will be recovered to and the source VM disk
trans-unit.target: On selecting each VM you can see more details about the source VM, target ESX server where the VM will be recovered to and the source VM disk

trans-unit.source: Click Next to begin the Recover Wizard
trans-unit.target: Click Next to begin the Recover Wizard

trans-unit.source: Select the Virtual Machines you want to recover
trans-unit.target: Select the Virtual Machines you want to recover

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: See the list of all the virtual machines that you can recover
trans-unit.target: See the list of all the virtual machines that you can recover

trans-unit.source: Run the Readiness Check. This will inform if the right parameters are configured to enable the latest tag recovery of the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: Run the Readiness Check. This will inform if the right parameters are configured to enable the latest tag recovery of the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Click Next if all the checks are successful else look at the log and resolve the errors.
trans-unit.target: Click Next if all the checks are successful else look at the log and resolve the errors.

trans-unit.source: In the VM Configuration step of the wizard, ensure that the recovery settings are correctly set.
trans-unit.target: In the VM Configuration step of the wizard, ensure that the recovery settings are correctly set.

trans-unit.source: In case the VM settings are different from the one you require, you can choose to change them.
trans-unit.target: In case the VM settings are different from the one you require, you can choose to change them.

trans-unit.source: Since we have already completed this action during the protection, you may choose to ignore it this time.
trans-unit.target: Since we have already completed this action during the protection, you may choose to ignore it this time.

trans-unit.source: Finally review the list of virtual machines that will be recovered.
trans-unit.target: Finally review the list of virtual machines that will be recovered.

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: Specify a recovery order to the virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Specify a recovery order to the virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: Note: The virtual machines are listed using the Computer Hostname.
trans-unit.target: Note: The virtual machines are listed using the Computer Hostname.

trans-unit.source: It might be difficult to map the computer hostname to the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: It might be difficult to map the computer hostname to the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: To map the names, you can go to the virtual machines dashboard in Azure IAAS and look at the hostname of the virtual machine.
trans-unit.target: To map the names, you can go to the virtual machines dashboard in Azure IAAS and look at the hostname of the virtual machine.

trans-unit.source: Give the recovery plan name and select Recover later in Recovery options.
trans-unit.target: Give the recovery plan name and select Recover later in Recovery options.

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: In case you want to recover right away you can choose to Recover now in the Recovery options.
trans-unit.target: In case you want to recover right away you can choose to Recover now in the Recovery options.

trans-unit.source: b.
trans-unit.target: b.

trans-unit.source: It is recommended to Recover later since the protection initial replication may not have completed
trans-unit.target: It is recommended to Recover later since the protection initial replication may not have completed

trans-unit.source: c.
trans-unit.target: c.

trans-unit.source: Finally click on Recover button to either save the plan or to trigger the recovery based on your Recovery options.
trans-unit.target: Finally click on Recover button to either save the plan or to trigger the recovery based on your Recovery options.

trans-unit.source: You can see the Recovery Status and see if it the plan is successfully saved.
trans-unit.target: You can see the Recovery Status and see if it the plan is successfully saved.

trans-unit.source: If you have chosen to recover later, you will be informed that the plan is created and you can recover later.
trans-unit.target: If you have chosen to recover later, you will be informed that the plan is created and you can recover later.

trans-unit.source: After the plan is created, you can choose to recover the virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: After the plan is created, you can choose to recover the virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: As a pre-requisite, you need to ensure that the virtual machines have completed synchronization.
trans-unit.target: As a pre-requisite, you need to ensure that the virtual machines have completed synchronization.

trans-unit.source: If Replication Status shows OK then the protection is completed and the RPO threshold has been met.
trans-unit.target: If Replication Status shows OK then the protection is completed and the RPO threshold has been met.

trans-unit.source: To confirm the replication pair’s health, you can go to the virtual machine properties and see the health of the replication.
trans-unit.target: To confirm the replication pair’s health, you can go to the virtual machine properties and see the health of the replication.

trans-unit.source: **Turn off the Azure virtual machines before you initiate the recovery.
trans-unit.target: **Turn off the Azure virtual machines before you initiate the recovery.

trans-unit.source: This will ensure that there is no split brain and your end customers will be served by one copy of the application.
trans-unit.target: This will ensure that there is no split brain and your end customers will be served by one copy of the application.

trans-unit.source: Only when you have successfully ensured that the Azure VMs are turned off continue to the steps below.**
trans-unit.target: Only when you have successfully ensured that the Azure VMs are turned off continue to the steps below.**

trans-unit.source: To begin recovering the virtual machines back to on-premise, you need to start the plan that is saved.
trans-unit.target: To begin recovering the virtual machines back to on-premise, you need to start the plan that is saved.

trans-unit.source: On the vContinuum select to Monitor the plans.
trans-unit.target: On the vContinuum select to Monitor the plans.

trans-unit.source: The wizard will list the plans that have been executed till now.
trans-unit.target: The wizard will list the plans that have been executed till now.

trans-unit.source: Select the Recovery node and select the plan that you want to recover.
trans-unit.target: Select the Recovery node and select the plan that you want to recover.

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: It will inform you that the plan has not yet started.
trans-unit.target: It will inform you that the plan has not yet started.

trans-unit.source: Click Start to begin the recovery.
trans-unit.target: Click Start to begin the recovery.

trans-unit.source: You can monitor the recovery of the virtual machines
trans-unit.target: You can monitor the recovery of the virtual machines

trans-unit.source: Once the VMs have been powered ON, you can connect to the virtual machines on your vCenter.
trans-unit.target: Once the VMs have been powered ON, you can connect to the virtual machines on your vCenter.

trans-unit.source: After failback has been completed you may want to protect the virtual machines once again.
trans-unit.target: After failback has been completed you may want to protect the virtual machines once again.

trans-unit.source: The below steps will help you re-configure the protection
trans-unit.target: The below steps will help you re-configure the protection

trans-unit.source: Check that the virtual machines on-premises are working and application is able to reach your end customers.
trans-unit.target: Check that the virtual machines on-premises are working and application is able to reach your end customers.

trans-unit.source: On the Azure Site Recovery portal, select the virtual machines and delete them.
trans-unit.target: On the Azure Site Recovery portal, select the virtual machines and delete them.

trans-unit.source: a.
trans-unit.target: a.

trans-unit.source: Select to disable the protection of the virtual machines.
trans-unit.target: Select to disable the protection of the virtual machines.

trans-unit.source: This will ensure that the VMs are no more protected.
trans-unit.target: This will ensure that the VMs are no more protected.

trans-unit.source: Go to the Azure IAAS virtual machines and delete the failed over VMs.
trans-unit.target: Go to the Azure IAAS virtual machines and delete the failed over VMs.

trans-unit.source: Delete the old VMs on vSpehere – these are the VMs that you previously failed over to Azure.
trans-unit.target: Delete the old VMs on vSpehere – these are the VMs that you previously failed over to Azure.

trans-unit.source: On the ASR portal select to protect the virtual machines recently failed over.
trans-unit.target: On the ASR portal select to protect the virtual machines recently failed over.

trans-unit.source: Once the VMs are protected, you can add them to a recovery plan and be continuously protected.
trans-unit.target: Once the VMs are protected, you can add them to a recovery plan and be continuously protected.
